I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan 
and  (ii)  a  proposed  grant,  both  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  for  the  Climate  Change  and  Disaster-
Resilient Water Resources Sector Project. 
 
2. 
The project will strengthen the climate change and disaster resilience of the water sector 
through modernized and well-maintained infrastructure, enhanced agricultural and on-farm water 
management, and improved disaster risk management (DRM).1 The project interventions will be 
both structural (including civil works and equipment) and nonstructural (including capacity building 
and demonstration activities). The interventions will focus on the Ferghana Valley in the southwest 
of the country and the Chui River Basin in the north, which are vulnerable to flooding, landslides 
(including mudflows), and drought risks that are likely to be exacerbated by climate change. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Context  of  vulnerability.  With  steep  mountain  geography  and  variable  weather 
conditions,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  is  highly  disaster-prone.  Disasters  triggered  by  climatic  and 
geophysical natural hazards are frequent and estimated to cost the country equivalent to 1.0%–
1.5%  of gross  domestic product  annually.2  Much  of  the  population  is  vulnerable and exposed, 
with limited resources to  mitigate and  recover from  disaster  impacts.  A primary  avenue  of this 
vulnerability  is  through  the  water  resources  sector,  including  irrigated  agriculture.  Irrigation  is 
critical for sustained agricultural production in the Kyrgyz Republic, which engages about 30% of 
the population (including about 45% of the lower-income rural population) and contributes about 
15% of gross domestic product.3 
 
Notable  water-related  disaster  events  include  severe  droughts  (2009  and  2014)  in  the 
4. 
northern  districts,  and  landslides  (2003  and  2004)  and  flooding  (2007  and  2012)  in  the 
southwestern districts.4 Future climatic change is likely to increase the frequency and magnitude 
of such events. Drought and associated water stress may occur more often as temperatures rise. 
Precipitation  and  snowmelt  patterns  are  expected  to  change  adversely,  with  water  availability 
declining in the face of growing competing demands.5 Landslides and floods are likely to become 
more frequent as a result of melting permafrost and more intense precipitation events.6 
 
Sector  institutional  context.  The  Ministry  of  Emergency  Situations  (MOES)  and  the 
5. 
Department of Water Resources and Melioration (DWR) under the Ministry of Agriculture, Food 
Industry, and Melioration are the primary agencies for DRM in the water resources sector. The 
MOES is the national institution for cross-sector civil protection, including disaster prevention and 
rehabilitation, along the main water courses. The Agency for Hydrometeorology under the MOES,

 2 

or  KyrgyzHydromet,  is the  national  institution for  hydrometeorological  monitoring and  analysis, 
including forecasting and warning of extreme weather-related events. The DWR constructs and 
maintains  the  main  canals  of  the  irrigation  systems,  including  associated  flood  management 
infrastructure.  Irrigation  infrastructure  management  is  coordinated  with  the  local  water  users 
associations  (WUAs),  which  construct  and  maintain  the  lower-level  (on-farm  and  inter-farm) 
canals. 
 
6. 
Water resources management and DRM are afforded high government priority. However, 
following  the  collapse  of  the  Soviet  Union,  Kyrgyz  water  resources  infrastructure  has  become 
dilapidated  and  inefficient,  offering  insufficient  protection  and  resilience  to  natural  hazards.7 
Irrigation infrastructure design and management is often suboptimal, with inadequate investment 
and maintenance by the DWR and WUAs. As a result, systems often do not have enough water 
for  the  cropped  area  and  have  sustainable  but  low-productivity  operations  with  significant 
opportunity  for  improvement.  The  capacity  of  WUAs  is  highly  variable,  and  WUAs  often  have 
insufficient and inequitable stakeholder representation, particularly of women, in decision-making 
processes.  Female  farmers  contribute  significantly  to  cultivating  activities  but  are  at  a 
disadvantage when accessing financial markets and agricultural value chains because of social 
and  knowledge  barriers.  Community  consultation  has  identified  strong  demand  and  need  for 
investments in lower-level canal infrastructure, and improved integration with modernized primary 
and secondary canals. The MOES has insufficient equipment to fully undertake its planned annual 
disaster prevention and rehabilitation (including recovery) works, and lack of recent investment 
means  the  equipment  is  used  beyond  its  economic  lifetime,  thereby  reducing  efficiency. 
KyrgyzHydromet  is  hampered  by  a  sparse  monitoring  network  and  insufficient  forecasting 
capacity. This overall situation is likely to be aggravated by growing and competing water demand 
from  population  and  economic  growth  and  increased  demands  from  agriculture,  households, 
industry, and the energy sector. 
 
7. 
Government sector strategy. The project is a priority climate adaptation project in the 
Kyrgyz Climate Investment Programme.8 Strengthening resilience to climate change and extreme 
weather  events  in  water  resources  management  is  underpinned  by  the  country’s  Water  Code 
(2005) and the government’s national development, climate change, and sector strategies. The 
Water  Code is  the  primary  water-related  legal  act  and  is  based  on  the principles of  integrated 
water resources management, organization of water resources management by river basin, and 
user participation in decision making. The national development program for 2018–2022 includes 
proactive management of disaster and climate change risks, and prioritizes the construction and 
rehabilitation  of  irrigation  infrastructure  with  improved  water  efficiency.9  The  Strategy  for  the 
Comprehensive  Protection  of  the  Population  and  the  Territory  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  from 
Emergency  Situations  for  2018–2030  seeks  to  reduce  disaster  losses  through,  among  other 
measures, improved monitoring, forecasting, and construction of protective structures that require 
about Som9.8 billion in funding for 2018–2022.10 The State Programme on the Development of 
Irrigation of the Kyrgyz Republic for 2017–2026 seeks more productive use of water resources 
through  the  construction  and  modernization  of  infrastructure  and  the  introduction  of  improved 
technologies, which require about Som59 billion in funding.11

8. 
Opportunities and lessons learned. The project was initially identified and elaborated 
under  an  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  regional  technical  assistance  through  stakeholder 
consultations  on  investment  needs  for  climate  change  and  disaster  resilience  in  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic (footnote 6). To mitigate future climate change and disaster impacts on the livelihoods 
of  vulnerable  communities,  these  consultations  identified  that  (i)  water  access  and  availability 
should  be  made  more  resilient  to  future  disruptions,  variability,  and  change;  (ii)  resilience  to 
extreme weather events should be improved; and (iii) institutional capacity for climate and disaster 
risk  management  and  response  should  be  strengthened.  An  earlier  ADB  regional  technical 
assistance undertook a detailed assessment of the agricultural and water resources sector in the 
country and identified priority investment needs for irrigation infrastructure.12 The ADB Agricultural 
Area  Development  Project,  completed  in  2009  and  rated  successful,  improved  agricultural 
management,  rehabilitated  irrigation  infrastructure,  and  supported  business  development.13 
Lessons from ADB activities in the country and region call for (i) incorporating climate change and 
disaster risk assessment into infrastructure design; (ii) optimizing water resources use through a 
more  inclusive  and  gender-sensitive  participatory  planning  and  management  process;  and (iii) 
supporting  infrastructure  investment  with  improved  capacity  for  water  resources  monitoring, 
forecasting, and warning of extreme events. 
 
9. 
Development  partners  support  climate  resilience  and  DRM  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic, 
including  the  water  resources  sector,  through  investment  projects  and  technical  assistance.14 
During project preparation, ADB worked closely with development partners, including through the 
Kyrgyz Republic Pilot Program for Climate Resilience financed by the Climate Investment Funds, 
to ensure appropriate coordination on project activities, avoid overlap of investments and target 
areas,  and  incorporate  lessons  from  earlier  and  ongoing  projects.  The  World  Bank  supports 
(i) capacity building and equipment modernization of KyrgyzHydromet for improved weather data 
collection  and 
the  Central  Asian  Hydromet  Modernization  Project, 
(ii) strengthening  of  WUAs  and  water  resources  data  management  under  the  National  Water 
Resources  Management  Project  (Phase  1),  and  (iii)  on-farm  irrigation  infrastructure  and 
management  under  the  Agriculture  Productivity  and  Nutrition  Improvement  Project.  United 
Nations agencies and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe support climate 
resilience  and  transboundary  water  resources  management  in  the  Chu-Talas  Basin  through 
several projects. The United Nations Development Programme is preparing in parallel a mudflow 
protection and forecasting project. However, the country has large investment needs, particularly 
for irrigation infrastructure and equipment for sustainable and effective DRM capacity.

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

investment needs are large and additional support is required for more productive and efficient 
results.  The  project  will  (i)  design  and  build  climate  change  and  disaster-resilient  irrigation 
infrastructure;  (ii)  strengthen  irrigation  management  arrangements,  including  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M), between the WUAs and the local DWR offices; (iii) enhance and strengthen 
WUAs and WUA subgroups; and (iv) build executing agencies’ capacity on procurement, financial 
management, and environmental and social safeguards. The project establishes a template for 
climate change and disaster-resilient investment that may be scaled up and replicated. 
 
B. 
 
11. 
The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  losses  in  the  agriculture  and  water 
resources  sectors  from  extreme  weather  events  reduced.17  The  project  will  have  the  following 
outcome: climate change and disaster resilience of infrastructure and water security improved.18 
 
C. 
 
Output 1: Irrigation infrastructure protected and modernized. The project will protect 
12. 
and  modernize  irrigation  systems  to  improve  the  productivity  and  disaster  resilience  of  about 
20,000  hectares  of  irrigated  land.  It  will  upgrade  and  construct  main  (primary  and  secondary) 
canals;  lower-level  (inter-farm  and  on-farm)  canals;  and  associated  infrastructure  such  as 
protective  mudflow  crossing  structures,  cross-regulators,  and  offtakes.19  Infrastructure  design 
specifications will incorporate disaster risk mitigation measures for future climate conditions. The 
project will mobilize a participatory planning and design process involving the DWR, WUAs, WUA 
subgroups,  and  other  key  stakeholders  to  ensure  equitable  and  sustainable  outcomes.  One 
representative subproject has been selected and developed during project preparation and two 
or  three  additional  subprojects  will  be  identified  for  investment  during  implementation.20 
Community-based  contracting  will  be  pilot  tested  for  lower-level  canal  modernization  in  the 
representative subproject and will be expanded to further subprojects if shown to be successful. 
 
13. 
Output 2: Irrigation system and agricultural land management enhanced. The project 
will strengthen management and O&M of target irrigation systems, including practical drought and 
climate risk management, to ensure the sustainability of the investment benefits. In conjunction 
with  output  1,  under  the  participatory  planning  process,  the  project  will  (i)  reorganize  and 
strengthen the institutional capacity of WUAs and WUA subgroups for more effective organization; 
and (ii) build the capacity of the DWR representatives, WUA and WUA subgroup representatives, 
and farmers on effective and resilient irrigation system management, water use, and agronomy. 
The project will develop  and implement joint DWR–WUA irrigation system management plans, 
including  water  delivery  scheduling  and  O&M  financing  and  planning.  WUA  on-farm  water 
management  and  agricultural  management  plans  with  gender  elements  will  be  developed, 
including  irrigation  scheduling,  cropping  patterns,  and  cultural  methods,  and  will  be  supported 
with  capacity  building  for  farmers  and  community  members  (including  women),  such  as 
comparative field trials and farmer field days.

 Output  3:  National  disaster  risk  management  capacity  improved.  The  project  will 
14. 
support capacity building and upgrade equipment for national DRM in the water resources sector. 
Heavy  machinery  and  specialist  equipment  for  preventive  and  rehabilitation  works,  such  as

areas and an information system for enhanced data collection, processing, and flood warning will 
be pilot tested for improved efficiency and accuracy.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
20. 
The project has been assessed as technically feasible and designed to ensure the long-
term resilience and sustainability of the investments. A feasibility study has been undertaken for 
a  representative  subproject  that  considered  future  water  availability  and  flood  risks,  which 
provides  the  basis  for  the  additional  subprojects.  The  participatory  planning,  design,  and 
management  process  under  outputs  1  and  2  will  facilitate  a  more  engaged  decision-making 
process among stakeholders for optimal use of water resources. Sustainable management plans 
for infrastructure and equipment will be developed under outputs 2 and 3 to ensure best practice 
asset management and O&M of project investments. 
 
B. 
 
21. 
The  project  is  expected  to  be  economically  viable  and  sustainable.  The  representative 
subproject is estimated to have an economic internal rate of return of 16%. The monetized benefit 
is improved farmer income from optimal agricultural production that is more resilient to climate 
change and disaster risk. The nonquantifiable benefits include protection of the wider population 
from avoided impacts of flood damage through the improved and expanded preventive works and 
enhanced flood forecasting. The risks to the sustainability of the investments, particularly irrigation 
schemes, are mitigated through the development and implementation under outputs 2 and 3 of 
sustainable O&M plans, including institutional arrangements, financing, and cost sharing. To be 

Economic and Financial 

7 

 

 8 

 

Governance 

eligible  to  participate  in the  project  and  benefit  from  investments, WUAs  and WUA  subgroups 
must demonstrate financial sustainability and undergo financial management training. ADB has 
secured government assurance that adequate finance will be provided to meet its share of O&M 
costs to implement these plans. Within the framework of the project, ADB will engage in broader 
policy  dialogue  with  the  government  and  other  development  partners  on  ensuring  adequate 
financing of irrigation and DRM assets. 
 
C. 
 
22. 
The  pre-mitigation  financial  management  risk  is  substantial  because  the  executing 
agencies  (i)  have  limited  experience  in  ADB  policies  and  requirements  for  project  financial 
management and (ii) generally do not apply international standards for accounting and internal 
and external audit. The risks will be mitigated through the (i) establishment of a PIU with a qualified 
chief  accountant  and  a  financial  specialist;  (ii)  establishment  of  a  PIU  financial  management 
system, including the use of commercial accounting software by the PIU; (iii) provision of on-the-
job  support  and  training  to  the  PIU  by  a  project  implementation  consultant;  and  (iv)  annual 
management audits of the PIU by an external firm on procurement processes, payment processes 
and systems (including bank reconciliation), and fixed-asset management. 
 
23. 
The pre-mitigation procurement risk is substantial because the executing agencies have 
(i) limited experience in ADB procurement policies and requirements and (ii) insufficient internal 
systems  in  place  for  governance  on  procurement.  The  risks  will  be  mitigated  through  the 
(i) establishment  of  a  PIU  with  qualified  procurement  specialists,  (ii)  establishment  of  a 
procurement management system in the PIU, (iii) provision of on-the-job support and training to 
the PIU by a project implementation consultant, (iv) annual PIU management audits, and (v) use 
of prior review procedures. 
 
24. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government,  the  DWR,  and  the  MOES.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 21). 
 
D. 
 
25. 
The  vulnerability  of  the  lower-income  population  engaged  in  agriculture  is  a  result  of 
several  factors,  including  small  farm  lots,  limited  access  to  finance,  inefficient  practices  and 
technologies,  and  dilapidated  infrastructure.  The  project  is  expected  to  help  alleviate  these 
challenges by providing climate-resilient irrigation infrastructure, improving institutional DRM, and 
improving agricultural and water management. These will mitigate the negative effects of extreme 
weather events on properties and livelihoods. 
 
The project is classified effective gender mainstreaming as it addresses the gender issues

relevant  to  the  project,  such  as  (i)  women’s  participation  in  WUAs  and  WUA  subgroups,  (ii) 
gender-sensitive  plans  for  improved  irrigation  and  agricultural  management,  and  (iii)  women’s 
participation in training.27

Environment (category B). A draft initial environmental examination (IEE), including an 
environmental management plan (EMP), has been prepared by the executing agencies for the 
representative subproject and disclosed on ADB’s website. Additional subprojects will be selected 
during project implementation and an environmental assessment and review framework has been 
prepared and disclosed on ADB’s website. The executing agencies will rule out civil works and 
subprojects with significant environmental impacts (only category B and C will be eligible), and an 
IEE  will  be  performed  for  each  subproject.  An  EMP  will  provide  appropriate  mitigation  and 
monitoring  measures  and  a  capacity  building  plan  for  each  subproject;  contractors  will  be 
responsible for  implementing the mitigation  measures.  Project  impacts  during  construction are 
expected  to  be  site-specific  and  temporary  and  related  to  the  construction  of  the  subproject 
components. Potential impacts during the operation phase are related to limited local capacity to 
maintain  the  functionality  of  the  components,  with  expected  positive  impacts  from  the 
rehabilitation works. 
 
29. 
Involuntary  resettlement (category  B).  A  draft  land acquisition  and  resettlement  plan 
(LARP)  has  been  prepared  by  the  executing  agencies  for  the  representative  subproject  and 
disclosed on ADB’s website. Additional subprojects will be selected during project implementation 
and a land acquisition and resettlement framework has been prepared and disclosed on ADB’s 
website. The executing agencies will rule out category A civil works and subprojects, avoid land 
acquisition, and minimize resettlement impacts. Appropriate social safeguard documents will be 
prepared,  approved,  and  fully  implemented  before  any  works  commence.29  Surveys  and 
consultation carried out during preparation for the representative subproject identified two affected 
households  with  12  household  members.30  No  land  acquisition  is  required,  and  resettlement 
compensation  for  the  affected  assets  was  calculated  and  budgeted  as  part  of  the  draft  LARP 
preparation. No household will experience severe impacts or belongs to vulnerable groups.

The PIU will recruit a full-time safeguards specialist who will receive on-the-job training 
and  support  from  the  project  implementation  consultant  on  monitoring  the  EMP  and  LARP 
implementation during construction. A grievance redress mechanism will be established by the 
PIU  following  the  LARP,  the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  framework,  the  environmental 
assessment and review framework, and the IEE and EMP to assist affected persons in resolving 
grievances and complaints. The PIU will submit semiannual safeguard reports to ADB for review 
and disclosure.

ASSURANCES
